title: France Yields on Its Unilateral Internet Tax
summary: Responding to U.S. pressure, France just announced it's hitting pause on it's digital services tax and will await the OECD.. In July, France became the first country to impose a digital services tax (DST) on American tech companies, threatening jobs and setting a dangerous precedent. In "Let's Make a Deal on Tech Taxes" (op-ed, Jan. 14) French Minister of the Economy and Finance Bruno Le Maire said his country's DST was "a matter of fairness," while also saying "national taxes aren't the answer," and countries should work with the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) on an international solution.

title: Another Look at America's Economic Growth
summary: The average annual rise in GDP per person was $505.1 in the first 20-year period (1950-70) and $626.5 since 2000.. In reviewing Dietrich Vollrath's "Fully Grown: Why a Stagnant Economy Is a Sign of Success" (Bookshelf, Jan. 13), Edward Glaeser looks at the idea that: "While America's real gross domestic product grew at a blistering rate of 4.2% a year between 1950 and 1970, real GDP growth has increased by only 2% annually since 2000. A sense of decline infects our national mood." He provides some support, refinements and additions to Mr. Vollrath's arguments that much of the effect is due to changes in the human capital embedded in the labor force and increasing specialization in low-growth industries.

title: An Explanation of Modern Monetary Theory
summary: MMT doesn't advocate "monetizing" deficits rather than issuing bonds. MMT's point is that it doesn't matter. The debt can always be paid by creating money.. N. Gregory Mankiw's critique of Modern Monetary Theory (MMT) in "A Skeptic's Guide to Modern Monetary Theory" is flawed ("Notable & Quotable: MMT," Jan. 15). MMT observes that a government with its own currency faces no financial constraints, but all countries face real resource constraints. If a budget deficit adds more demand than the real economy can handle, inflation will result.

title: The CRA Often Helps the Better Off, Not the Poor
summary: Gentrification is inevitable and often beneficial to urban communities, but it requires no help from government.. In "The Plot to Politicize Banking" (op-ed, Jan. 15), Phil Gramm and Michael Solon argue that the Community Reinvestment Act encouraged risky lending by banks before the 2008 financial crisis. Some academic evidence does suggest a conflict between CRA performance and bank safety and soundness.

title: Bloomberg on Gun Rights
summary: Michael Bloomberg believes that the "average citizen" should not carry a gun. His security detail consists of "average citizens.". Regarding your editorial "Bloomberg Misfires on Jack Wilson" (Jan. 17): Former New York mayor and presidential hopeful Michael Bloomberg believes that the "average citizen" should not carry a gun. His security detail consists of "average citizens." He's just another liberal who doesn't eat his own cooking.

title: A 224-Year-Old Tavern That Inspires Cool Girl Denim Label B Sides
summary: Claire Lampert co-founded jeans company B Sides, which counts Sofia Coppola as a fan. Her cozy, colorful house upstate is one of her main sources of inspiration. In 2012, one pair of jeans changed Claire Lampert's life. A design consultant by day, Lampert was running a creative studio in Brooklyn's Bushwick neighborhood as a side project, finding, shooting and selling vintage clothing under the name Where I Was From. She had one pair of patchwork jeans, though, that she never wanted to give up. When fashion executive Stacy Daily visited the studio and saw the jeans, she proposed working on something similar with Lampert. The two made a few pairs of their own, reworking vintage jeans by patching different pairs onto each other with a sewing machine in the studio. The first iteration of their self-funded company, B Sides, named for the B side of records, was born.
